posts.name: Derek W.
posts.cooked:
I love Onshape. I’ve been using it personally and in my class since it was released to education customers in 2016. Our team has always used Solidworks since it is an industry standard. This season, since we were snowed out for a week I thought it might be a good time to switch over to Onshape since we were at home. Well, now that Onshape is down I am feeling one of the downsides of a cloud-based service.

Please come back up soon Onshape!

Welcome to Onshape's home for real-time and historical data on system performance.

posts.name: Chris Cross
posts.cooked:
Whew!  Thank goodness!  I thought it was just me.

I mean, yeah.  Hope it comes back online soon.
It was working good about an hour ago.  I bet (hope) they will get it up again soon.

posts.name: Drew B.
posts.cooked:
Yup, there’re a bunch of engineers working on getting it back up as fast as possible. You can monitor the status at https://status.onshape.com/ if you want to track it.

(I realized too late that OP included that link in their original post, oh well)

posts.name: David
posts.cooked: I don’t know if you have the answer to it but, Will all of the CAD models be saved? Will they “Restore” some files to the latest “stable version” and delete the last few changes before the crash?

posts.name: Ryder Schwarz
posts.cooked: I live, laugh, love onshape. Except, it’s down.

posts.name: Elliot S
posts.cooked: Someone did an oopsy…

posts.name: Chris Cross
posts.cooked: Looks like it’s back!  That was quick.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked:
Just to be clear, as a general statement:

An outage like this does not inherently mean there is data loss.

posts.name: Drew B.
posts.cooked: Whatever the last feature you completed was before you started seeing the issue is what the servers have captured - there shouldn’t be any amount of rollback. At most I’d expect one feature if it wasn’t completed.

posts.name: Derek W.
posts.cooked: It’s kind of working for me, but some features aren’t working (inserting things into assemblies for example).

posts.name: Chris Cross
posts.cooked: Yeah.  May have spoken too soon.  But, progress!

posts.name: David
posts.cooked: Of course it doesn’t mean it. But our team was working hard on the models for a few hours now, and now it crashed. Just wanted to understand if we need to think about chaning our schedule.

posts.name: Drew B.
posts.cooked: Nope, I don’t think you have anything to worry about. The outage is annoying from a productivity standpoint, but lost work shouldn’t be an issue!

posts.name: Ethan
posts.cooked: It’s back up everybody!

posts.name: Dan
posts.cooked: Kinda sorta? Let me in for a while but not everything was working, and it appears to be hanging still.

posts.name: Derek W.
posts.cooked: Not for me.

posts.name: Drew B.
posts.cooked: It’s going to be a slow spin up to monitor everything and not create new issues. I wouldn’t expect normal performance or speeds for a little bit.

posts.name: Ty Tremblay
posts.cooked:
Derek W.:

Well, now that Onshape is down I am feeling one of the downsides of a cloud-based service.

I wonder how long Onshape has to be down in order to make up for all the times Solidworks has crashed on me in the past.

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: It’s back up!
